Welcome to UAV Minimum Snap Trajectory Planner’s documentation!¶

Modules¶

class iuav.trajectory.optimal_time.TrajectoryPlotter[source]¶

Bases: object

Class for plotting the trajectory and its derivatives.

static plot_trajectory(waypoints, polys_x, polys_y, polys_z, time_stamps, iteration=None, clear_plot=False, flag=False)[source]¶

Plot the minimum snap trajectory in 3D.

Parameters:

  • waypoints (torch.Tensor) – Waypoints in 3D space.

  • polys_x (torch.Tensor) – Polynomial coefficients for x axis.

  • polys_y (torch.Tensor) – Polynomial coefficients for y axis.

  • polys_z (torch.Tensor) – Polynomial coefficients for z axis.

  • time_stamps (torch.Tensor) – Time stamps for each segment.

  • iteration (int, optional) – Current iteration number for optimization.

  • clear_plot (bool, optional) – Whether to clear the plot before plotting.

  • flag (bool, optional) – Whether to display the plot immediately.

static plot_trajectory_and_derivatives(waypoints, polys_x, polys_y, time_stamps)[source]¶

Plots the trajectory and its derivatives (position, velocity, acceleration, jerk, and snap).

Parameters:

  • waypoints (torch.Tensor) – Waypoints of the trajectory.

  • polys_x (torch.Tensor) – Polynomial coefficients for the x-coordinate.

  • polys_y (torch.Tensor) – Polynomial coefficients for the y-coordinate.

  • time_stamps (torch.Tensor) – Timestamps for each segment.

class iuav.trajectory.optimal_time.TrajectoryUtils[source]¶

Bases: object

Utility functions for trajectory calculations.

static calculate_time_vector(time, order, derivative_order)[source]¶

Generates a time vector for polynomial evaluation based on the given time, polynomial order, and derivative order.

Parameters:

  • time (float) – Scalar time value.

  • order (int) – Order of the polynomial.

  • derivative_order (int) – The order of the derivative.

Returns:

A tensor representing the time vector.

Return type:

torch.Tensor

static compute_Q_matrix(poly_order, derivative_order, start_time, end_time)[source]¶

Computes the Q matrix used in the quadratic cost function for polynomial optimization.

Parameters:

  • poly_order (int) – Order of the polynomial.

  • derivative_order (int) – The order of the derivative.

  • start_time (float) – Start time of the segment.

  • end_time (float) – End time of the segment.

Returns:

A tensor representing the Q matrix.

Return type:

torch.Tensor

static evaluate_polynomial(polynomial_coefficients, time, derivative_order)[source]¶

Evaluates a polynomial at a given time for a specific derivative order.

Parameters:

  • polynomial_coefficients (torch.Tensor) – Coefficients of the polynomial.

  • time (float) – Scalar time value.

  • derivative_order (int) – The order of the derivative.

Returns:

The evaluated value of the polynomial at the given time.

Return type:

float

static evaluate_polynomials(polynomial_coefficients, time_stamps, times, derivative_order)[source]¶

Evaluates multiple polynomials over a range of times for a specific derivative order.

Parameters:

  • polynomial_coefficients (torch.Tensor) – Coefficients of the polynomials.

  • time_stamps (torch.Tensor) – Timestamps for each segment.

  • times (torch.Tensor) – Tensor of times to evaluate the polynomials.

  • derivative_order (int) – The order of the derivative.

Returns:

A tensor of evaluated polynomial values.

Return type:

torch.Tensor

class iuav.trajectory.optimal_time.UAVTrajectoryPlanner(waypoints, total_time, poly_order, start_vel, start_acc, end_vel, end_acc, dtype=torch.float32, device='cpu')[source]¶

Bases: Module

UAV Trajectory Planner using minimum snap optimization.

Parameters:

  • waypoints (torch.Tensor) – Waypoints of the trajectory.

  • total_time (float) – Total time for the trajectory.

  • poly_order (int) – Order of the polynomial.

  • start_vel (torch.Tensor) – Starting velocity.

  • start_acc (torch.Tensor) – Starting acceleration.

  • end_vel (torch.Tensor) – Ending velocity.

  • end_acc (torch.Tensor) – Ending acceleration.

  • dtype (torch.dtype) – Data type for computations. Default is torch.float32.

  • device (str) – Device for computations. Default is ‘cpu’.

init_time_segments(waypoints, total_time)[source]¶

Initializes time segments based on waypoint distances and total time.

evaluate_trajectory(T, plot_trajectory=False, iteration=None)[source]¶

optimize_time_segments(waypoints, total_time)[source]¶

forward(waypoints, total_time)[source]¶

Main function to optimize the trajectory and solve for polynomial coefficients.

evaluate_cost_function(polys_x, polys_y, polys_z, T)[source]¶

Evaluates the cost function for the given polynomial coefficients and time segments.

Parameters:

  • polys_x (torch.Tensor) – Polynomial coefficients for the x-coordinate.

  • polys_y (torch.Tensor) – Polynomial coefficients for the y-coordinate.

  • polys_z (torch.Tensor) – Polynomial coefficients for the z-coordinate.

  • T (torch.Tensor) – Time segments.

Returns:

The total cost of the trajectory.

Return type:

float

evaluate_trajectory(T, plot_trajectory=False, iteration=None)[source]¶

Evaluates the trajectory given the time segments, and optionally plots the trajectory.

Parameters:

  • T (torch.Tensor) – Time segments.

  • plot_trajectory (bool, optional) – Whether to plot the trajectory.

  • iteration (int, optional) – Current iteration number for optimization.

Returns:

The cost of the trajectory.

Return type:

float

forward(waypoints, total_time)[source]¶

Main function to optimize the trajectory and solve for polynomial coefficients.

Parameters:

  • waypoints (torch.Tensor) – Waypoints of the trajectory.

  • total_time (float) – Total time for the trajectory.

Returns:

Polynomial coefficients for x coordinates. torch.Tensor: Polynomial coefficients for y coordinates. torch.Tensor: Polynomial coefficients for z coordinates. torch.Tensor: Optimized time segments. list: Loss history.

Return type:

torch.Tensor

  • waypoints (torch.Tensor) – Waypoints of the trajectory.

  • total_time (float) – Total time for the trajectory.

Returns:

A tensor of initialized time segments.

Return type:

torch.Tensor

optimize_time_segments(waypoints, total_time)[source]¶

Optimizes the time segments for the trajectory to minimize the cost.

Parameters:

  • waypoints (torch.Tensor) – Waypoints of the trajectory.

  • total_time (float) – Total time for the trajectory.

Returns:

Optimized time segments. list: Loss history.

Return type:

torch.Tensor

solve_minimum_snap(waypoints, time_stamps, poly_order, start_vel, start_acc, end_vel, end_acc)[source]¶

Solves the minimum snap problem to find polynomial coefficients for the trajectory.

Parameters:

  • waypoints (torch.Tensor) – Waypoints of the trajectory.

  • time_stamps (torch.Tensor) – Time segments.

  • poly_order (int) – Order of the polynomial.

  • start_vel (torch.Tensor) – Starting velocity.

  • start_acc (torch.Tensor) – Starting acceleration.

  • end_vel (torch.Tensor) – Ending velocity.

  • end_acc (torch.Tensor) – Ending acceleration.

Returns:

Polynomial coefficients for the trajectory.

Return type:

torch.Tensor

forward(waypoints, time_stamps=None)[source]¶

Defines the computation performed at every call.

Should be overridden by all subclasses.

Note

Although the recipe for forward pass needs to be defined within this function, one should call the Module instance afterwards instead of this since the former takes care of running the registered hooks while the latter silently ignores them.

solve_minimum_snap(waypoints, time_stamps, poly_order, start_vel, start_acc, end_vel, end_acc)[source]¶

Solve the minimum snap problem for a single axis.

Parameters:

  • waypoints (Tensor) – waypoints

  • time_stamps (Tensor) – time stamps for each segment

  • poly_order (int) – polynomial order

  • start_vel (float) – start velocity

  • start_acc (float) – start acceleration

  • end_vel (float) – end velocity

  • end_acc (float) – end acceleration

  • dtype (data type) – data type for tensors

  • device (str) – computation device (‘cpu’ or ‘cuda’)

Returns:

coefficients of the polynomial

Return type:

Tensor

Defines the computation performed at every call.

Should be overridden by all subclasses.

Note

Although the recipe for forward pass needs to be defined within this function, one should call the Module instance afterwards instead of this since the former takes care of running the registered hooks while the latter silently ignores them.

training: bool¶
class iuav.controller.geometric_controller.MultiCopter(mass, g, J, dt)[source]¶

Bases: NLS

observation(state, input, t=None)[source]¶
Parameters:

  • state (Tensor) – The state of the dynamical system

  • input (Tensor) – The input to the dynamical system

  • t (Tensor) – The time step of the dynamical system. Default: None.

Returns:

The observation of the system at the current step

Return type:

Tensor

Note

The users need to define this method and can access the current system time via the property systime. Don’t introduce system transision noise in this function, as it will be used for linearizing the system automaticalluy.

pose_normalize(state)[source]¶
rk4(state, input, t=None)[source]¶
state_transition(state, input, t=None)[source]¶
Parameters:

  • state (Tensor) – The state of the dynamical system

  • input (Tensor) – The input to the dynamical system

  • t (Tensor) – The time step of the dynamical system. Default: None.

Returns:

The state of the system at next time step

Return type:

Tensor

Note

The users need to define this method and can access the current time via the property systime. Don’t introduce system transision noise in this function, as it will be used for linearizing the system automaticalluy.

forward(error, error_dot, ff=None)[source]¶
Parameters:

  • error – error value \(\mathbf{e}(t)\) as the difference between a desired setpoint and a measured value.

  • error_dot – The rate of the change of error value.

  • ff – feedforward system input appened to the output of the pid controller

This method is used to reset the internal error integrity.
